Equipment Breakdown Coverage; The Department objects to including service contract coverages in an insurance policy, within the same policy document. Service contracts are regulated under different laws under Title 20 regulations and require the obligor to obtain a permit to engage in the service contract business. Additionally, a service contract requires a separate consideration from the one for an insurance contract. There must be a clear distinction between the two types of coverage and how each affects consumers rights and obligations. Pursuant to ARS 20-1095 et seq. an entity issuing service contracts needs to obtain a permit in order to do so. Issuing service contracts without the appropriate registration constitutes an unlicensed activity and is prohibited by law. Additionally, combining two disassociated coverages within the same policy without notice that the consumer is entering into two separate coverage contracts causes consumer harm and confusion and is in violation of Arizonas Unfair Practices Act. See ARS 20- 443, 461. An insurance policy coverage is distinct and separate from the ones of a service contract and each can affect a consumers rights and obligations differently. In this case, Farmers Insurance Company of Arizona and Policy Form 93-7726 and any other forms that contain similar coverages, does not comply with the statutory provisions cited above. The company does not hold a service company permit and is not authorized to sell service contracts in Arizona. Furthermore, the current form filing includes both insurance coverage and service contract coverage within the same form without any explanations or information relating to the differences between the two coverages which will cause consumer confusion. Any claims under an insurance policy are treated differently from those under a service contract and the implications for a consumer under each coverage are very distinct. Without clearly explaining the differences and providing sufficient information to a consumer to make a well-informed decision, the current form language misrepresents pertinent facts and insurance policy provisions relating to coverage. The Department objects to the current form language. This filing will remain open until such time as this language is removed.  In addition any related Rate or Rule filings will need to be revised or withdrawn. Objection 4           Comments: Loss History - Weather-related Claims Page 7 of 28, Loss History The second bullet states: "Two or more claims reported within three years." Minnesota does not permit the use of claims based on weather events to surcharge a homeowners policy. Minnesota Statute §65A.28, subd. 8 authorized the commissioner to promulgate rules to specify the grounds for nonrenewal, reduction in limits of coverage or elimination of coverage. The rules must limit the grounds to specific factors, one of which is the insureds loss experience, not to include natural causes. Minnesota Rules Chapter 2880 were promulgated under this authority. Under these rules a transfer from one rating plan to another, if the transfer results in a premium increase, is a nonrenewal. The rules set out specific conditions that, if met, would constitute nonrenewal, including a surcharge to a premium for a condition that increases the potential for loss. By implication, where the conditions are not met, the outcome would be inverted. That is, if the plan is transferred but there is no increase in premium, then a nonrenewal has not occurred. Likewise, a surcharge applied for any reason other than a condition that increases the potential for loss would be a nonrenewal. The statutory and regulatory frameworks draw a distinction between natural causes and conditions. This distinction matters. As discussed above, a surcharge based on a condition is specifically excluded from the nonrenewal definition in Minn. R. 2880.0100, subp. 5. However, the next section of Chapter 2880 makes clear that the conditions in question are those that can be remediated by the homeowner: No insurer shall refuse to renew a policy of homeowners insurance unless based on one or more reasons which shall be limited to the following  Refusal of the insured to eliminate known conditions which increase the potential for loss after notification by the insurer that the condition must be removed. (Minn. R. 2880.0200(E)) Likewise, Chapter 2880 provides clarity on what constitutes natural causes that, per Minn. Stat. §65A.29, cannot provide the basis of a nonrenewal decision. Minn. R. 2880.0200(G) states that losses caused by natural causes including but not limited to lightning, wind, or hail cannot be counted as losses during the experience period for the purposes of nonrenewal. What emerges is a clear distinction between those things in the control of the insured (conditions) and those not in the control of the insured (natural causes).
